8439FB10DFE601311D8368A86D17958E.description: identify roles in group situations (e.g., student, family member, peer member).

8439B8F0DFE601311D8268A86D17958E.description: identify examples of individual struggles and their influence and contributions (e.g., Sitting Bull, Louis Riel, Chief Plenty Coups, Evelyn Cameron, Helen Keller, Mohandas Gandhi, Rosa Parks).

84397440DFE601311D8168A86D17958E.description: identify characteristics of American Indian tribes and other cultural groups in Montana.

84392150DFE601311D8068A86D17958E.description: identify and describe ways families, groups, tribes and communities influence the individual's daily life and personal choices.

8438B7F0DFE601311D7F68A86D17958E.description: describe ways in which expressions of culture influence people (e.g., language, spirituality, stories, folktales, music, art, dance).

843868E0DFE601311D7E68A86D17958E.description: identify the ways groups (e.g., families, faith communities, schools, social organizations, sports) meet human needs and concerns (e.g., belonging, self worth, personal safety) and contribute to personal identity.

84382880DFE601311D7D68A86D17958E.description: Students demonstrate an understanding of the impact of human interaction and cultural diversity on societies.

8437E780DFE601311D7C68A86D17958E.description: identify and describe examples in which science and technology have affected economic conditions (e.g., assembly line, robotics, internet, media advertising).

8437A1D0DFE601311D7B68A86D17958E.description: explain the roles of money, banking, and savings in everyday life.

843757A0DFE601311D7A68A86D17958E.description: describe how personal economic decisions, (e.g., deciding what to buy, what to recycle, how much to contribute to people in need) affect the lives of people in Montana, United States, and the world.

8436FD70DFE601311D7968A86D17958E.description: distinguish between private goods and services (e.g., family car or local restaurant) and public goods and services (e.g., interstate highway system or U.S. Postal Service).

8436B4E0DFE601311D7868A86D17958E.description: identify basic economic concepts (e.g., supply and demand, price) that explain events and issues in the community.

843674A0DFE601311D7768A86D17958E.description: give examples of needs and wants; scarcity and choice (e.g., budgeting of allowance, trading cards).

84363230DFE601311D7668A86D17958E.description: Students make informed decisions based on an understanding of the economic principles of production, distribution, exchange, and consumption.

8435E8B0DFE601311D7568A86D17958E.description: explain the history, culture, and current status of the American Indian tribes in Montana and the United States.

84359A00DFE601311D7468A86D17958E.description: recognize that people view and report historical events differently.

84354E50DFE601311D7368A86D17958E.description: identify and illustrate how technologies have impacted the course of history (e.g., energy, transportation, communications).

8434E960DFE601311D7268A86D17958E.description: identify and describe famous people, important democratic values (e.g., democracy, freedom, justice) symbols (e.g., Montana and U.S. flags, state flower) and holidays, in the history of Montana, American Indian tribes, and the United States.

8434A930DFE601311D7168A86D17958E.description: examine biographies, stories, narratives, and folk tales to understand the lives of ordinary people and extraordinary people, place them in time and context, and explain their relationship to important historical events.

84346680DFE601311D7068A86D17958E.description: use a timeline to select, organize, and sequence information describing eras in history.

843423C0DFE601311D6F68A86D17958E.description: identify and use various sources of information (e.g., artifacts, diaries, photographs, charts, biographies, paintings, architecture, songs) to develop an understanding of the past.

8433DEF0DFE601311D6E68A86D17958E.description: Students demonstrate an understanding of the effects of time, continuity, and change on historical and future perspectives and relationships.

84339810DFE601311D6D68A86D17958E.description: describe and compare the ways in which people in different regions of the world interact with their physical environments.

84334100DFE601311D6C68A86D17958E.description: identify and distinguish between physical system changes (e.g., seasons, climate, weather, water cycle, natural disasters) and describe the social and economic effects of these changes.

8432D4A0DFE601311D6B68A86D17958E.description: use appropriate geographic resources (e.g., atlases, databases, charts, grid systems, technology, graphs, maps) to gather information about local communities, reservations, Montana, the United States, and the world.

843291C0DFE601311D6A68A86D17958E.description: describe how human movement and settlement patterns reflect the wants and needs of diverse cultures.

84324F40DFE601311D6968A86D17958E.description: describe and illustrate ways in which people interact with their physical environment (e.g., land use, location of communities, methods of construction, design of shelters).

84320B20DFE601311D6868A86D17958E.description: locate on a map or globe physical features (e.g., continents, oceans, mountain ranges, land forms) natural features (e.g., flora, fauna) and human features (e.g., cities, states, national borders).

8431C4E0DFE601311D6768A86D17958E.description: identify and use various representations of the Earth (e.g., maps, globes, photographs, latitude and longitude, scale).

84318240DFE601311D6668A86D17958E.description: Students apply geographic knowledge and skills (e.g., location, place, human/environment interactions, movement, and regions).

843138E0DFE601311D6568A86D17958E.description: explore the role of technology in communications, transportation, information processing or other areas as it contributes to or helps resolve problems.

8430F7E0DFE601311D6468A86D17958E.description: describe factors that cause conflict and contribute to cooperation among individuals and groups (e.g., playground issues, misunderstandings, listening skills, taking turns).

8430B5D0DFE601311D6368A86D17958E.description: identify and explain the individual's responsibilities to family, peers and the community, including the need for civility, respect for diversity and the rights of others.

84307430DFE601311D6268A86D17958E.description: explain how governments provide for needs and wants of people by establishing order and security and managing conflict.

843030D0DFE601311D6168A86D17958E.description: identify the major responsibilities of local, state, tribal and federal government.

842FD070DFE601311D6068A86D17958E.description: recognize local, state, tribal and federal governments and identify representative leaders at these levels (e.g., mayor, governor, chairperson, president).

842F7C80DFE601311D5F68A86D17958E.description: explain the purpose and various levels of government.

842F3690DFE601311D5E68A86D17958E.description: Students analyze how people create and change structures of power, authority, and governance to understand the operation of government and to demonstrate civic responsibility.

842EF060DFE601311D5D68A86D17958E.description: use information to support statements and practice basic group decision making strategies in real world situations (e.g., class elections, playground and classroom rules, recycling projects, school stores).

842EB090DFE601311D5C68A86D17958E.description: evaluate information quality (e.g., accuracy, relevance, fact or fiction).

842E6CA0DFE601311D5B68A86D17958E.description: identify and practice the steps of an inquiry process (i.e., identify question or problem, locate and evaluate potential resources, gather and synthesize information, create a new product, and evaluate product and process).

842E20A0DFE601311D5A68A86D17958E.description: Students access, synthesize, and evaluate information to communicate and apply social studies knowledge to real world situations.
